# Working memory has limited capacity (feature #1)

Think of working memory as the set of resources for temporarily _holding_ and _manipulating_ information. 

Analogy used often: a working desk. There is enough space for the things you are working on right now, not much else...

<div style="text-align: center;">
<img src="https://freesvg.org/img/school-desk-flat.png" alt="School desk" style="width:30%;">
</div>


# Measuring working memory capacity: span

[Classic **span** tasks measure pure (short-term) storage capacity:]{.fragment} [participants hear or see sequences of items (digits, letters, words)]{.fragment} [and must recall them in order]{.fragment}. [Span is the _maximum number of items_ a person can correctly repeat, often reported to be around 7 +- 2.]{.fragment}

[Few and relatively simple processing: encoding and recall.]{.fragment}

[Optional: <a href="https://www.psytoolkit.org/experiment-library/experiment_digitspan.html">Link to demo of digit span task</a>]{.fragment}

Three different components handle storage of information (e.g., visuo-spatial, verbal-phonological) or manage access to that information.

```{dot}
//| fig-width: 8
digraph {
    rankdir=TD
    bgcolor="transparent"
    
    A [label="central executive"];
    B [label="phonological loop"];
    C [label="visuospatial sketchpad"];

    A -> {B; C} [dir="both"]
    
    
}
```

:::
::::


_"House windows" exercise_ to see how the three components work together

Work out how many windows are there in your house? 

- You retreive from long-term memory and manipulate a mental image of your house as you “walk through” it room by room (visuospatial sketchpad)

- As you progress, you keep a count of the number of windows by rehearsing the numbers out loud or not. (phonological loop)

- You will have followed a strategy: deciding which rooms to visualize next, keeping track of progress, and ensuring the count is updated (central executive),


# Measuring component-specific capacity: some examples

**Phonological/Verbal Working Memory:**

- _Digit Span_: Recall sequences of digits in order
- _Letter Span_: Recall sequences of letters in order
- _Word Span_: Recall sequences of words in order

**Visuospatial Working Memory:**

- _Corsi Block Tapping Test_: Recall sequences of spatial locations. [Optional: <a href="https://www.psytoolkit.org/experiment-library/experiment_corsi2.html">link to Corsi span test</a>]{.fragment}
- _Visual Patterns Test_: Recall patterns in a grid



# Complex span tasks (optional: not necessary for this module)

**Classic** span tasks = measure _how much_ you can hold.

**Complex** span tasks = measure how well you can hold information _while doing something else_.

[They require to:]{.fragment}

- resist interference from additioanl processing task 
- keep the memory items active

[Compared to classic span tasks, better association with higher-order cognition (executive functions)]{.fragment}

[Example: <a href="https://www.psytoolkit.org/experiment-library/experiment_aospan.html">link to the operation span task</a>]{.fragment}

[Working memory's limited capacity (feature #1) implies that we can't process all information at once. We need to **select**...]{.fragment} ['that's one of the things attention does]{.fragment}

::: aside
:::{.fragment}
What other things does attention do other than selecting (_orienting_)? General _alertness_ (being vigilant) and _executive control_ (monitoring, regulating). <a href="https://germanogallicchio.github.io/learning/JXHC_1055/04">More info</a>
:::

# Orienting of attention {.scrollable}


::::{.columns}
:::{.column}
**Endogenous**

- "endo" = from the inside
- voluntary, intentional
- determined by the person
- top-down
- **goal-directed**
:::
:::{.column}
**Exogenous**

- "exo" = from the outside
- involuntary, not intentional
- determined by the environment
- bottom-up
- **stimulus-driven**
:::
::::

:::{.column}

[You are in a noisy place.]{.fragment} 
[You choose to attend to one speaker (endogenous orienting).]{.fragment}
[Your attention is captured (distracted) by a salient, personally relevant cue (like hearing your name from your back) (exogenous orienting).]{.fragment}

"Quiet Eye" as much a phenomenon as a variable.

<br>

As a _variable_

- The QE is a duration of time, units of (milli)seconds
- Eyes on the critical location or object (e.g., ball in golf putting)
- It starts before movement initiation (“QE onset”)
- It ends when the gaze deviates from the location or object of a certain amount (“QE offset”)


As a _phenomenon_

[Extensive reports in literature that:]{.fragment}

- experts have a longer QE than novices
- QE is longer for successful than successful performance
- it is trainable

:::
::::

_Interpretations_ / Why is the QE beneficial to performance?

- Attention and perception
- Postural-kinematic quiescence
